text: PBMCs from CF patients do not produce increased amounts of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> upon inflammasome stimulation

text: Previous studies have shown that the loss of CFTR results in increased NF-kappaB activity and pro-inflammatory cytokine secretion [ 4 ] , [ 5 ] , [ 32 ] , [ 36 ] , [ 37 ] .

To further examine this relationship , PBMCs from CF patients and healthy adult controls were stimulated with PAO1 , LPS+ATP , and LPS+Poly ( dA : dT ) , to activate the NLRC4 , NLRP3 , and AIM2 inflammasomes , respectively .

By 24 hours of stimulation , CF PBMCs did not produce increased amounts of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Fig . 5a ) or IL-8 ( Fig . 5b ) when compared to healthy controls .

text: However , we did notice a transient decrease ( P < 0.001 ) in the amount of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> produced by CF cells in response to LPS+ATP at 6 hours ( data not shown ) .

text: Stimulation of PBMCs with P . aeruginosa that lacks <extra_id_0> exsA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( PAO1deltaexsA ) , a key regulator of type III secretion , produced three-fold less <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> compared to the parental PAO1 strain by 24 hours ( Fig . 5a ) .

text: Inflammasome stimulation without priming did not result in any <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in either CF or control PBMCs .

text: Contrary to our hypothesis , these results indicate that PBMCs from CF patients do not display increased production of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with inflammasome activation nor do they suggest any increased basal or induced NF-kappaB activity .

text: These results are consistent with our observation that caspase-1 activity is not different between CF and control PBMCs ( Fig . 4 ) .
